column3: IPv6 support should be enabled by default, disabled by necessity.\n
@jgarzik That's what this does...\n
What is the practical difference between USE_IPV6=0 and USE_IPV6=-? One compiles it in, but leaves no way to use it, the other just doesn't compile it in.\n
-onlynet=ipv6 should work, no?\n
If you call SetLimited(NET_IPV6) explicitly, -onlynet=ipv6 will just disable all other networks, and there won't be any network left.\n
That's why it's in an 'else' clause\n
Oops, missed that in the diff. ACK.\n

Found and fixed some build bugs:
1. Omitting USE_IPV6 in Bitcoin-Qt effectively disabled it
2. The preprocessor might evaluate the right-hand side of && even if the left hand side is false, so complained if USE_IPV6 was undefined

weak ACK.  Would prefer a better system for including and overriding USE_FOO defaults.  Some build systems look for a file "makefile.local" or "makefile.cfg" or whatever.  If it exists, read it and use it to adjust the defaults.\n
GNUmakefile can be used for that purpose (I do this).\n
Would be nice to not introduce something that does not work on Windows or makes building even harder to do @GNUmakefile ;).\n
@Diapolo GNUmakefile is more of an out-of-tree config thing. Windows has .BAT files :P\n
Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/751b8eb120375a1a045d55f267d2d93d807ab649 for binaries and test log.\n
ACK.\n
So with Qt, now do I need to supply "USE_IPV6=1" or is that also default for Qt ^^?\n
It's default.\n
It has been default for a long time. IPv6 is not exactly experimental anymore :)\n
Shouldn't this be !defined(USE_IPV6) || !USE_IPV6 ?\n
If USE_IPV6 is not defined, then there's no support compiled in to disable.\n
Right.\n
